Comments_List: I developed increased familiarity with the works of several major philosophers, especially Lacan and Butler.

I was able to witness a unique approach to teaching, one that looks at Antigone in various contexts, attempting to draw out ethical questions from each. The extent to which this project was successful is a bit unclear, but I appreciate the flexibility in discussion, for it tolerated and encouraged different ways to think about interpretation and argument.
I learned how to write short and extended critiques analyzing the interpretations of the play to stimulate questions for better class discussion, which the professor was helpful in encouraging.

I found some of the seminar discussions to be unsatisfying and unproductive at times, but on the whole the readings were interesting and I gained some valuable insights from the student presentations and the professor's comments.

The course gave a lot of opportunities for work with short essays and a presentation, as well as a culminating project, which all forced us to consider the texts in different lights. The professor was a little slow with grading, which caused anxiety for students who were considering dropping or Credit/D-ing the class by midterms, but became better as the year went on, and the feedback was very helpful.

I would if they had a particular interest in the subject materialthe intersection of philosophy and literature, Hegel, Lacan, Butler, Heideggerand was hoping to engage with short but extremely challenging texts once a week.
